SENT.plain: Two previously healthy children experienced serious neurologic complications in the course of severe S. aureus septicaemia
The first patient developed right hemiparesis and stupor due to a left frontal abscess
The second patient, admitted with signs of meningeal infection, developed acute bacterial endocarditis followed by late cerebral embolism causing coma and death
In both patients, cerebral CT was a useful rapid diagnostic acid
When the S. aureus septicaemic patient develops acute bacterial endocarditis, regardless of his haemodynamic state, early valve replacement may prevent harmful cerebral embolic phenomena
